The issue happens when the project is upgraded to @angular/\*@11.1.x ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: 11.0.9 ### Description `ngFor` seemingly stopped working and doesn't render anything. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction The working version with reproduction steps: https://github.com/dezsiszabi/ng11-bug-report-1-working The non-working version with reproduction steps: https://github.com/dezsiszabi/ng11-bug-report-1-not-working The only difference between the repositories is the version of angular used. Issues.Title: Angular Dashboard Framework & Ng New Schematics/--collection
Issues.Body:
There is a **huge void for business applications using dashboards**. While this is prevalent in most applications, every time I do a site/app for a company, they have an angular dashboard, I noticed people reinventing the wheel, every single time, and most often its common requirements implement wrong. If you look at Java JSR just around dashboards, but many are trying to retrofit angular in there. 


### Description
This both a feature request and a sample, so we can create schematics of an base dashboard that can house responsive widgets that communicate with each other/ using collections `--collection Widgets/Dashboard`



i.e. a dashboard sample and CLI scaffold to similar to creating a page, it would be very helpful to create a dashboard with widgets, which can communicate with each other.



![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21086190/106695713-29cb4d80-65a9-11eb-993d-7832d8cf7b72.png)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/21086190/106695734-32238880-65a9-11eb-9edf-ed36231cce4c.png)

Issues.Title: fix(common): allow number or boolean as http params
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist
Please check if your PR fulfills the following requirements:

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#commit
- [x] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [x] Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)


## PR Type
What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [x] Bugfix
- [ ] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] angular.io application / infrastructure changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:


## What is the current behavior?

Currently, the HTTP client expects string values for parameters, forcing us to cast numbers or boolean.
For example, if `page` is a number, we have to do something like:

```ts
this.http.get('/api/config', { params: { page: `${page}` } });
```

Issue Number: #23856 (but does not address the Date part of the issue)

## What is the new behavior?

Allows to use number and boolean directly as HTTP params, instead of having to convert it to string first.

```ts
this.http.get('/api/config', { params: { page }});
```

`HttpParams` has also been updated to have most of its methods accept number or boolean values.



## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No


<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->


## Other information
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(common): allow number or boolean as http params" (#40663)

Issues.Title: Make `Testability` and `TestabilityRegistry` tree-shakable
Issues.Body:
The `packages/core/src/testability/testability.ts` file contains some classes (such as `Testability` and `TestabilityRegistry`) that are used for testing only, but the way they are provided in Angular (see `packages/core/src/platform_core_providers.ts`) and used (see `packages/core/src/application_ref.ts`) are not tree-shakable.

Quick investigation done by Misko indicated that this would require some complex deprecation of code and or have the testability be lazy loaded by the protractor. We can also try to use a pattern that was used by `HammerModule` (so if testability logic is needed, a new NgModule should be imported), but this would likely be a breaking change.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Make `Testability` and `TestabilityRegistry` tree-shakable" (#40662)

Issues.Title: Deprecate `SafeStyle` and `DomSanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustStyle`
Issues.Body:
_(copied from internal tracker)_

The `SafeStyle` type is returned from the `DomSanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustStyle` method. Both of these APIs are apart of style sanitization in Angular. With the style sanitization refactor work, there will no longer be any need for these APIs in the framework, therefore, both the `SafeStyle` and `DomSanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustStyle` APIs will need to be deprecated.

The following steps need to be completed:
* Deprecate `SafeStyle` in the API docs (@deprecated)
* Deprecate `DomSanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustStyle` in the API docs (@deprecated)
* Emit a warning message when `DomSanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustStyle` is used
* Add entries to deprecation guide

Related design doc: https://hackmd.io/_sF2TzXLSiuuYbY88MpdQA?view
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Deprecate `SafeStyle` and `DomSanitizer.bypassSecurityTrustStyle`" (#40659)

Issues.Title: Need to run ngcc twice to output Ivy compatible files for modules with dependencies on other modules needing Ivy outputs
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package `ngcc` ### Is this a regression? No, I have noticed this behavior on Angular v9 - 11. ### Description I am building a components library that exposes each component as its own individual package with isolated versioning and installation. I understand this is an odd pattern and we are considering moving away from it due to a variety of difficulties, but it has exposed an issue with the ngcc cli tool. Per Angular documentation [guidelines](https://angular.io/guide/creating-libraries#publishing-your-library), I do not publish the Ivy version of these components. Because we publish View Engine compatible components, our consumers must run ngcc if they want to use the Ivy compiler in their own applications. Due to this individual component publish architecture, there are instances where a component is dependent on a different component. For example, our `Button` component is dependent on our `Icon` component. When consumers run `ngcc` after installing both the `Button` and `Icon` packages to their `node_modules`, `ngcc` fails to output Ivy compatible files for the `Button` package on the first run because it says its dependency `Icon` is not Ivy compatible. Interestingly, the first run of `ngcc` outputs Ivy compatible files for the `Icon` package after this initial error. On a second run, since the `Icon` package is now Ivy compatible, it properly outputs Ivy compatible files for the `Button` package. First Run of `ngcc`: ![Screen Shot 2021-02-01 at 10 37 13 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38677277/106502868-c68ecd80-6479-11eb-9f1b-c3f57062d8df.png) ![Screen Shot 2021-02-01 at 10 38 09 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38677277/106502877-c989be00-6479-11eb-92cb-281eed87ad7c.png) ![Screen Shot 2021-02-01 at 10 39 23 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38677277/106502885-ce4e7200-6479-11eb-8faa-58ea59ed9ded.png) Second Run of `ngcc`: ![Screen Shot 2021-02-01 at 10 41 01 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38677277/106503061-08b80f00-647a-11eb-8888-658dd385dcaa.png) ![Screen Shot 2021-02-01 at 10 41 09 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38677277/106503068-09e93c00-647a-11eb-9f87-0c50ccbce4e0.png) ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction Unfortunately, these npm modules are internal to my company and require credentials to access/install. In order to replicate this issue, one could publish two dummy packages to npm with one having a dependency on the other then try to install them. This would take some work to setup and doesnt seem entirely necessary to pinpoint the issue as explained above. I am happy to screenshare or walk through some debugging steps if need be. ## üî• Exception or Error ![Screen Shot 2021-02-01 at 10 46 02 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38677277/106503609-baefd680-647a-11eb-8257-9fc902d3b049.png) ![Screen Shot 2021-02-01 at 10 46 11 AM](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/38677277/106503619-bcb99a00-647a-11eb-932c-b94e8ca7489c.png) ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** **Behavior noted in Angular CLI v9.1+ through v11.1.1** 

Angular CLI: 11.1.1
Node: 12.18.4
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 11.1.1
... animations, cli, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Issues.Title: Single build with multiple configurationw vs multiple builds with single configuration each
Issues.Body:
# üìö Docs or angular.io bug report ### Description A clear and concise description of the problem... The angular documentation on multiple build configurations, could be clearer about having multiple build configurations. Specifically, it would be good to have clearer documentation on building with multiple configurations. When to run single build with many configurations vs when to run multiple builds with one confuguration each. It's on: https://angular.io/guide/workspace-config#alternate-build-configurations But it would also help to be on: https://angular.io/cli/build under the --configuration option section. The part that tripped my team up was this: "If multiple configurations change the same setting, the last-set value is the final one." Would be good to call out something along the line of: If you need all of the values for the same setting, instead of just the last one, you need to run multiple builds commands, one after another. For example, in the case where each configuration changes the output path and the base href, you probably want to run:` ng build -c CONF1G1 && ng build -c CONFIG 2` rather than `ng build -c CONFIG1,CONFIG2` as the second command would put everything under the CONFIG2 output path and base href. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ### What's the affected URL?** https://angular.io/... https://angular.io/guide/workspace-config#alternate-build-configurations ### Reproduction Steps** ### Expected vs Actual Behavior** ## üì∑Screenshot ## üî• Exception or Error
## üåç Your Environment ### Browser info ### Anything else relevant?

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/cli): resolve migration collections from containing package
Issues.Body: This change ensures that migration collections defined in a package's `ng-update` metadata are resolved from the containing package.  This avoids issues that may arise from package manager hoisting behavior which can result in the wrong migration collection being chosen.  The `--migrate-only` option already contained this resolution logic and now the full update contains it as well.

### Description
I have a big site which use a lot of things, like I need `three.js` to create a webgl view, and also I'm using libraries like `anychart`. I know there are a lot of chart library to choose, but we use anychart for the gantt chart.

so when I build the app, angular simply bundles `three.module.js`  and `anychart-bundle.min.js` directly into the chunks. I'm using the lazy load module to separate these, but not all pages in that module use these things, so I'm wondering if there is a way to separate these commonjs bundle into another lazy load chunk, and ignore these chunk when optimizing code? I hope these would increase the building time.

### Describe the solution you'd like
provide an option to extract some commonjs library into a separate lazyload chunk.


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I've tried to use webpack magic comment and use dynamic `import`, when using `dynamic import`, I have to loose all the type hint of that library, which is a huge pain when coding.

Issues.Title: Multiple web workers results in unavoidable "...is part of the TypeScript compilation but it's unused." warning.
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->

- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] extract-i18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc


### Is this a regression?

Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: @angular/cli@10.0.1
(This is the last version we used before updating to 11)

### Description

An Angular project that contains two or more web workers, which run different code, will generate the following warnings, which can not be resolved or disabled:

`
Warning: filename is part of the TypeScript compilation but it's unused.
Add only entry points to the 'files' or 'include' properties in your tsconfig.
`

This is because there is a single tsconfig.worker.json, regardless of how many workers there are defined. For example, if I have two workers defined, each with their own code, each importing different modules, I'll get warnings because the modules are getting compiled for the bundles for both workers.

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction

### Create a new project:
```ng new webwrkr```

### Add two workers
```
ng generate web-worker worker-1
ng generate web-worker worker-2
```

### Modify the app.component.ts to create the workers:
```
  ngOnInit() {
    let worker1 = new Worker('./worker-1.worker', { name: "worker-1", type: "module" });
    let worker2 = new Worker('./worker-2.worker', { name: "worker-2", type: "module" });
  }
```

### Create something for the workers to import:
worker-1.import.ts
```
export class Worker1Stuff {
    public doSomething() {
        console.log("Hello from worker 1");
    }
}
```

worker-2.import.ts
```
export class Worker2Stuff {
    public doSomething() {
        console.log("Hello from worker 2");
    }
}
```

### Modify the workers to import and use the above classes:
worker-1.worker.ts:
```
/// <reference lib="webworker" />
import { Worker1Stuff } from './worker-1.import';

addEventListener('message', ({ data }) => {
  const response = `worker response to ${data}`;
  postMessage(response);

  let worker1Stuff = new Worker1Stuff();
  worker1Stuff.doSomething();
});
```

worker-2.worker.ts
```
/// <reference lib="webworker" />
import { Worker2Stuff } from './worker-2.import';

addEventListener('message', ({ data }) => {
  const response = `worker response to ${data}`;
  postMessage(response);

  let worker2Stuff = new Worker2Stuff();
  worker2Stuff.doSomething();
});
```

## üî• Exception or Error
Running "ng build" results in the following output, with the given warnings:
```
‚àö Browser application bundle generation complete.
‚àö Copying assets complete.
‚àö Index html generation complete.

Initial Chunk Files | Names         |      Size
vendor.js           | vendor        |   2.09 MB
polyfills.js        | polyfills     | 127.65 kB
main.js             | main          |  56.61 kB
runtime.js          | runtime       |   6.15 kB
styles.css          | styles        | 118 bytes

                    | Initial Total |   2.28 MB

Build at: 2021-02-02T19:35:15.270Z - Hash: 52377778ecf6aa486b1c - Time: 6077ms

Warning: C:/TEMP/temp-proj/webwkr/src/app/worker-2.import.ts is part of the TypeScript compilation but it's unused.
Add only entry points to the 'files' or 'include' properties in your tsconfig.

Warning: C:/TEMP/temp-proj/webwkr/src/app/worker-2.worker.ts is part of the TypeScript compilation but it's unused.
Add only entry points to the 'files' or 'include' properties in your tsconfig.

Warning: C:/TEMP/temp-proj/webwkr/src/app/worker-1.import.ts is part of the TypeScript compilation but it's unused.
Add only entry points to the 'files' or 'include' properties in your tsconfig.

Warning: C:/TEMP/temp-proj/webwkr/src/app/worker-1.worker.ts is part of the TypeScript compilation but it's unused.
Add only entry points to the 'files' or 'include' properties in your tsconfig.
```

The warnings are caused by this line in tsconfig.worker.json:
```
  "include": [
    "src/**/*.worker.ts"
  ]
```

Attempting to remove this include results in an error. Ideally, there should be a way of disabling these warnings, or specifying different tsconfig files for each worker.

## üåç Your Environment
```
Angular CLI: 11.1.2
Node: 12.13.1
OS: win32 x64

Angular: 11.1.1
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1101.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1101.2
@angular-devkit/core            11.1.2
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.1.2
@angular/cli                    11.1.2
@schematics/angular             11.1.2
@schematics/update              0.1101.2
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.1.3
```

Issues.Title: Angular ignores the ESM code in my npm package, still gives CommonJS optimization bailout warning
Issues.Body:
### Description I want to **author** (not consume!) an npm package, which itself **contains no Angular code**, so that it can be **used in an Angular 10+ project** without getting CommonJS optimization bailout warnings. I do not want to merely suppress these warnings using `"allowedCommonJsDependencies"`, but attack the root cause of the warnings. My package already contains ESM-style modules, *as well as* CommonJS (and even minified UMD). There are both ES6 (ES2015) and ES5 code versions available. Here's the start of my package.json: ```json { "name": "@tubular/util", "version": "3.3.0", "description": "Miscellaneous utility functions", "browser-es5": "dist/web5/index.js", "browser-es6": "dist/web/index.js", "main": "dist/es5/index.js", "module": "dist/index.js", "es2015": "dist/es6/index.js", "esm2015": "dist/index.js", "typings": "dist/index", "sideEffects": false, ``` The code at `dist/index.js` looks like this: ```typescript export * from './browser-graphics-util'; export * from './browser-util'; export * from './misc-util'; export * from './string-util'; ``` ...and all the code that is exported above is written in the ESM style, using `import`, not `require`. So why is Angular complaining about the CommonJS code, instead of happily grabbing the ESM code and using that instead, without any need for warnings? Full source code here: https://github.com/kshetline/tubular_util ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-zqghjw?file=src/app/hello.component.ts Since stackblitz doesn't show the warnings that can be seen when doing `npm start` or `npm run build`, so you'll have to download this project to see the problem. I suspect you've all see the warning before anyway: > WARNING in /Users/kshetline/programming_projects/svc-ng/node_modules/@tubular/time/dist/date-time.js depends on '@tubular/util'. CommonJS or AMD dependencies can cause optimization bailouts. ## üî• Exception or Error 

WARNING in /Users/kshetline/programming_projects/svc-ng/node_modules/@tubular/time/dist/date-time.js depends on '@tubular/util'. CommonJS or AMD dependencies can cause optimization bailouts.
(Not the exact error produced by the stackblitz sample code, but same general idea.) ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 

Angular CLI: 10.2.1
Node: 14.15.1
OS: darwin x64

Angular: 10.2.4
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router

Issues.Title: feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): detect and use tailwindcss in projects
Issues.Body:
This feature adds detection of the `tailwindcss` package (https://tailwindcss.com) and provides a mechanism to automatically include support. To enable tailwindcss for a project, two actions must be taken:
1) Install `tailwindcss` into the Angular workspace (`npm install -D tailwindcss`/`yarn add -D tailwindcss`)
2) Create a tailwindcss configuration file (`tailwind.config.js`) in either the workspace root or the project root.  A configuration file in the project root takes precedence over one in the workspace root.

When both conditions are met, the Angular CLI will initialize and integrate tailwindcss into the stylesheet build pipeline.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular-devkit/build-angular): detect and use tailwindcss in projects" (#19935)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): error with status code when response code is not 200
Issues.Body: During font inlining, a request can return a response status code other than 200. In which case, the contents of the page should not be inlined.

Issues.Title: Angular 11 with webpack 5 breaks with webpackMissingModule on recompilation
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [ ] new - [ ] build - [x] serve - [ ] test - [ ] e2e - [ ] generate - [ ] add - [ ] update - [ ] lint - [ ] extract-i18n - [ ] run - [ ] config - [ ] help - [ ] version - [ ] doc ### Is this a regression? No, breaks after moving to webpack 5 ### Description An Angular 11 app with webpack 5 breaks after recompilation (for changes on certain files) ``` Cannot find module '@angular/core' at webpackMissingModule ... ``` ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction - git clone https://github.com/difference-engine/ng-webpack5-missing-module.git - cd ng-webpack5-missing-module - yarn - yarn start - (go to http://localhost:4200/) - (edit app.module.ts and save) - refresh browser window, and you should see the error - (interestingly, doing the same with app.component.html or app.component.ts doesn't break things) ## üî• Exception or Error ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15520960/106600998-2328e000-6581-11eb-9333-1321086fc25c.png) ## üåç Your Environment 

Angular CLI: 11.1.2
Node: 14.15.1
OS: linux x64

Angular: 11.1.1
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1101.2
@angular-devkit/build-angular   0.1101.2
@angular-devkit/core            11.1.2
@angular-devkit/schematics      11.1.2
@angular/cli                    11.1.2
@schematics/angular             11.1.2
@schematics/update              0.1101.2
rxjs                            6.6.3
typescript                      4.0.5
**Anything else relevant?** Originally I had posted this on webpack https://github.com/webpack/webpack/issues/12561 reason for my suspicion was this recent change to `rebuildModule` in webpack 5 -> https://github.com/webpack/webpack/pull/11433 and the dependency of `AngularWebpackPlugin` on `rebuildModule` But my understanding of both the tools is fairly limited, and webpack folks think this might be a deeper incompatibility with webpack 5
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Angular 11 with webpack 5 breaks with webpackMissingModule on recompilation" (#19934)

Issues.Title: ELIFECYCLE Issue while installing angular CLI
Issues.Body:
Getting below error while installing Angular CLI
I have used below command

npm install -g @angular/cli

Below is the error:

hub.com/request/request/issues/3142

Roaming\npm\node_modules\@angular\cli\bin\ng

> @angular/cli@11.1.2 postinstall C:\Users\Administrator\AppData\Roaming\npm\nod
e_modules\@angular\cli
> node ./bin/postinstall/script.js

npm WARN rollback Rolling back @schematics/angular@11.1.2 failed (this is probab
ly harmless): EPERM: operation not permitted, scandir 'C:\Users\Administrator\Ap
pData\Roaming\npm\node_modules\@angular\cli\node_modules\@schematics'

##### Notes

-   using `~` is deprecated and can be removed from your code (**we recommend it**), but we still support it for historical reasons. 

Why you can removed it?
The loader will first try to resolve `@import` as relative, if it cannot be resolved, the loader will try to resolve `@import` inside [`node_modules`](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/#resolve-modules).

##### ‚ö† BREAKING CHANGES

-   minimum supported `webpack` version is `5`

##### Features

-   supported the [`resolve.byDependency`](https://webpack.js.org/configuration/resolve/#resolvebydependency) option, you can setup `{ resolve: { byDependency: { less: { mainFiles: ['custom', '...'] } } } }`

</details>

Issues.Title: The `doc` command never exits
Issues.Body:
When you for instance run `ng doc router`, then it does open the URL as expected, but then command never exits. You have to manually kill the process (e.g. CTRL-C). The reason for this is that it's using `open` internally and wraps it in a promise. However, the promise is never resolved, so the process will stay alive. Here's the code:

https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/efb97c87f023497dc59a2f4fa3825a2ca78606da/packages/angular/cli/commands/doc-impl.ts#L54-L58

I am not sure if I am missing something, but the promise should be resolved pretty much immediately, because `open` is also instructed to not wait.

I am happy to fix this in a PR.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "The `doc` command never exits" (#19912)

Issues.Title: feat(mat-error): Make mat-error politeness configurable and/or have a less disruptive default.
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

I would like for the `<mat-error>` component to not use `role="alert"` and instead use `aria-live="polite"` or at least make the politeness configurable via an Input binding as in many cases the assertive/interruptive announcement is harmful to the user.

#### Use Case

Assuming mat-errors can appear as a dynamic update (which they can, because form fields can validate on blur or while typing), that update needs to be expressed to the user in some form to comply with [WCAG 4.1.2](https://www.w3.org/TR/UNDERSTANDING-WCAG20/ensure-compat-rsv.html). AFAIK there is nothing that says that the user must be interrupted to do so. In most screen readers the usage of the `role="alert"`, on inline dynamic errors that occur when focus leaves a field, can cause the error message to supersede announcing the new control that has focus. This can lead to additional errors where the user changes the value of the wrong field


#### Implementation Details

Happy to contribute myself.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(mat-error): Make mat-error politeness configurable and/or have a less disruptive default." (#21781)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-select): Standard appearance select's ripple is not visible in high contrast mode
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

Stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-lh4cau?file=src/app/select-overview-example.html

Steps to reproduce:
1. Turn on high contrast mode
2.  Open Stackblitz and tab to the mat-select 
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

What behavior were you expecting to see?
Focus ripple should be visible.

#### Actual Behavior

What behavior did you actually see?
Focus ripple is not visible. Only seems to be an issue with `appearance="standard"`. Legacy works fine


#### Environment

- Angular: 11.0.3
- CDK/Material: 11.0.3
- Browser(s): Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows with High Contrast Mode
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-select): Standard appearance select's ripple is not visible in high contrast mode" (#21780)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-dialog): Interpolation and conditional don't work inside material dialogs in custom elements
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction Due the complexity to create the environment (custom elements running from an external web site), it is not possible to use StackBlitz to reproduce this issue. Instead, I created the following repo: https://github.com/gcherem/custom-elements-bug Steps to reproduce: 1. run npm run build:elements in widget folder to build the scripts 2. put widget/elements files in a web server (I used https://github.com/kzahel/web-server-chrome) 3. double-click html/index.html (depending where you put the scripts, you may need to adapt index.html to find the scripts) 4. click open modal button #### Expected Behavior Should show interpolated text and conditional structural (when satisfied) in material dialogs. By the other hand, everything works outside the dialog (main page). #### Actual Behavior Elements with interpolation {{ ...}} are not renderized at all. As well structural conditions (ngIf), even when the condition is true. ![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/47535363/106672456-d21fe880-658e-11eb-948d-44657f09785e.png) template ```html

Widget

line 1

line 2: {{ variable }}

line 3

line 4: This line also does not appear on modal

line 5

Cannot see lines 2 and 4 on modal

``` PS.: No error reported at the console #### Environment - Angular: 11.1.1 - CDK/Material: 11.1.1 - Browser(s): Chrome - Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOs Catalina
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-dialog): Interpolation and conditional don't work inside material dialogs in custom elements" (#21779)

Issues.Title: feat(cdk/testing): Create `WebDriverHarnessEnvironment`
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

There's not much Protractor-specific about the `ProtractorHarnessEnvironment`. We could make it more flexible by creating a more generic `WebDriverHarnessEnvironment` that works with WebDriver types rather than Protractor types. For backwards compatibility we would still need a version that works with Protractor types, but it could just be a thin wrapper.

#### Use Case

Enable users who use WebDriver but not Protractor to use harnesses in their tests.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(cdk/testing): Create `WebDriverHarnessEnvironment`" (#21777)

Issues.Title: bug(mat-grid-list): Remove <figure> element from inside mat-grid-tile
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

When using the mat-grid-tile element, Angular inserts a "figure" tag on page render. This can cause confusion for screen readers reading aloud the "figure" tag before reading the content inside the tile.
 
 
#### Expected Behavior

Content inside the mat-grid-tile should render as the programmer enters it, rather than inserting a "figure" tag. (If the programmer wishes to surround the content in a figure, they can enter that themselves).


#### Actual Behavior

The mat-grid-tile component renders a "figure" tag around the ng-content inserted by the programmer, causing unwanted behavior with screen readers.


#### Environment

- Angular: 9
- CDK/Material: 9.2.4
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-grid-list): Remove <figure> element from inside mat-grid-tile" (#21775)

Issues.Title: feat(date-range-picker): allow disabling one half of the range input
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

The user should be able to disable one half of the date range input (either the start or end date) but still allow a user to select a value for the other. Currently the date range picker acts broken if we try to disable one half: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-aihygj?file=src/app/date-range-picker-forms-example.html

#### Use Case

This supports use cases where the user needs to select a range, but the start or end date is fixed for some reason, e.g. editing a hotel reservation where its too late to change the check in date.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(date-range-picker): allow disabling one half of the range input" (#21773)

one date allow multiple color

Issues.Title: bug(MatTabGroup): StaticInjectorError thrown when using MatTabGroup with wrapper component
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

See this [Stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-mat-tab-group-wrapper?devtoolsheight=33&file=src/app/example-component.html)

Create a component that includes a `MatTabGroup` whose `MatTab` come inside `ng-content`
```html
<mat-tab-group #tabGroup>
     <ng-content></ng-content>
</mat-tab-group>
```
 
#### Expected Behavior

The `MatTabGroup` should not give an error, as it was the case with Angular 10 / Angular Material 10.
See this [stackblitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-mat-tab-group-wrapper-working-with-angular-10?file=package.json) for a working example with Angular 10 / Angular Material 10


#### Actual Behavior

The following error is thrown:
```
Error: StaticInjectorError(AppModule)[MatTab -> InjectionToken MAT_TAB_GROUP]:
StaticInjectorError(Platform: core)[MatTab -> InjectionToken MAT_TAB_GROUP]:
NullInjectorError: No provider for InjectionToken MAT_TAB_GROUP!
```


#### Environment

- Angular: 11.1.1
- CDK/Material: 11.1.1
- Browser(s): Tested in Chrome and Firefox
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Tested on macOS and Ubuntu
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatTabGroup): StaticInjectorError thrown when using MatTabGroup with wrapper component" (#21770)

Issues.Title: feat(MapMarkerClusterer): Add `options` input parameter
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Several components including GoogleMap and MapMarker have a `options` input parameter that allow to pass a complete options object. The wrapped APIs already support such an options object. The MarkerClusterer constructor is no exception.

For the sake of consistency, MapMarkerClusterer should also expose an `options` input.

#### Use Case

Currently:

```
<map-marker-clusterer
  [gridSize]="markerClustererOptions.gridSize"
  [maxZoom]="markerClustererOptions.maxZoom"
  [zoomOnClick]="markerClustererOptions.zoomOnClick"
  ...
>
  <map-marker
    *ngFor="let markerOptions of markerOptions"
    [options]="markerOptions.options"
  ></map-marker>
</map-marker-clusterer>
```

Instead, it would be more useful:

```
<map-marker-clusterer
  [options]="markerClustererOptions"
>
  <map-marker
    *ngFor="let markerOptions of markerOptions"
    [options]="markerOptions.options"
  ></map-marker>
</map-marker-clusterer>
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "feat(MapMarkerClusterer): Add `options` input parameter" (#21763)

Issues.Title: build: bump autoprefixer from 6.7.7 to 10.2.4
Issues.Body:
Bumps [autoprefixer](https://github.com/postcss/autoprefixer) from 6.7.7 to 10.2.4.
Release notes

Sourced from autoprefixer's releases.

10.2.4

  • Fixed browser names in npx autoprefixer --info.

10.2.3

  • Fixed PostCSS 8 support.

10.2.2

  • Fixed PostCSS 8 plugins compatibility.

10.2.1

  • Fixed transition-property warnings (by @Sheraff).

10.2 ‚ÄúSub rosa‚Äù

Autoprefixer 10.2 now has built-in TypeScript definitions. You do not need @types/autoprefixer anymore.

Thanks to @Semigradsky and DefinitelyTyped‚Äôs contributors.

@Sheraff also improved docs.

10.1 ‚ÄúPula‚Äù

Autoprefixer 10.1 improved min-resolution support.

@infusion added dpcm unit support and num2fraction with Fraction.js, which uses Farey Sequences as a rational approximation (more precise) and simplifies the fraction using continued fractions to …õ <0.001 afterward.

/* input */
@media (min-resolution: 113.38dpcm) {
  ‚Ä¶
}

/* output */
@media (-webkit-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3),
(min--moz-device-pixel-ratio: 3),
(-o-min-device-pixel-ratio: 3/1),
(min-resolution: 113.38dpcm) {
‚Ä¶
}

10.0.4

  • Fixed Cannot read property 'proxyOf' of undefined error (by @igorkamyshev).

10.0.3

  • Fixed substract to subtract value for mask-composite (by @crankysparrow).

10.0.2
